title: 105_s494
content: The Act is titled the "Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act" and it establishes prisoner copayments for health care services. The "Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act" introduces copayments for health care services for prisoners, defining terms like account, Director, health care provider, health care visit, and prisoner. The "Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act" defines a qualified health care visit as any health care visit except specific circumstances such as during incarceration intake, annual exams, emergencies, immunizations, or referrals by prison officials, with exceptions for prisoners under 18, pregnant, or as determined appropriate. The Director shall assess and collect copayments for health care services in federal prisons, including fees for qualified health care visits, prescription medications, and visits for mentally ill or disabled prisoners. The Director assesses and collects copayments for health care services in federal prisons, including fees for qualified health care visits, prescription medications, and visits for mentally ill or disabled prisoners. Fees are collected from the prisoner receiving the care or the prisoner responsible for causing the injury resulting in the visit. Fees are collected at the time of the visit or when the prisoner's account balance allows. The Director collects copayments for health care services in federal prisons, including fees for visits, medications, and visits for mentally ill or disabled prisoners. Prisoners with insufficient account balances can pay through an installment plan. Treatment cannot be refused due to financial reasons. Amounts collected are deposited in the Crime Victims' Fund. The Director must report to Congress annually on the amounts collected. The Director must report annually to Congress on the amounts collected under the Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act and analyze the impact on prisoners' health care visits. Prisoner copayments for health care services are required under the Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act.
